one_liner: This technique models a multi-server queue system that incorporates retrial queues and two-way communication under varying server states.
how_it_works: The multi-server two-way communication retrial queue allows incoming calls to enter a retrial queue when all servers are busy. During idle times, servers can make outgoing calls. The model also accounts for disasters that may cause server failures, requiring repairs. By analyzing the system's state transitions, performance metrics such as average queue size and server utilization can be derived.

steps: 1. Define the state space for the system including incoming and outgoing calls, retrial queue size, and server states.
2. Establish the transition rates for incoming calls, outgoing calls, and server states.
3. Use the matrix geometric method to derive the stationary distribution of the system.
4. Calculate performance indices based on the stationary probabilities.
5. Perform numerical experiments to validate the analytical results.
algorithm.core_equation: output = average size of retrial queue, average time spent in retrial queue, server utilization
algorithm.input_format: Parameters: arrival rate (λ), service rates (μ1, μ2, μw), retrial rate (ν), disaster rate (δ), repair rate (γ), vacation rate (η), probabilities of joining retrial queue (bb, bv, br), number of servers (c).
algorithm.output_format: Performance indices including average size of retrial queue, average time spent in retrial queue, server utilization, and probabilities of server states.

parameters.name: λ
parameters.effect: Higher arrival rates increase the average size of the retrial queue.

parameters.name: μ1
parameters.effect: Higher service rates for incoming calls reduce queue times.

parameters.name: μ2
parameters.effect: Higher service rates for outgoing calls improve overall system efficiency.

parameters.name: ν
parameters.effect: Higher retrial rates decrease the average time spent in the retrial queue.

parameters.name: δ
parameters.effect: Higher disaster rates increase server downtime.

parameters.name: γ
parameters.effect: Higher repair rates reduce the time servers are unavailable.

parameters.name: η
parameters.effect: Higher vacation rates can lead to increased queue lengths.

parameters.name: c
parameters.effect: More servers generally improve system performance.

complexity.practical_note: The performance of the model can vary significantly based on the parameters chosen.

use_when: Modeling telephony systems with high retry rates.
Designing call centers that require proactive customer follow-up.
Analyzing systems where server availability fluctuates due to disasters.
avoid_when: The system has a very low retry rate.
The application does not involve two-way communication.
The system is not subject to disasters or server failures.
